page_analysis.text_content:
Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, planters, and other projections

• Fireplaces shall be included in the gross floor area (counted one time) regardless of configura-
tion or design.
• Sheds, planters, and other projections that are higher than 5' count toward gross floor area
regardless of configuration or design.


Fig 14 Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, etc.

Note: In 2000, the city of Palo Alto
passed an ordinance prohibiting the
construction of new wood-burning fire-
places. For details about and possible
prohibition, see the
Chapter 9.06.030

Chimneys on the
upper floors DO
NOT COUNT

Height

Miscellaneous appendages e.g., tool
sheds, equipment enclosures, play
houses, etc., that are greater than 5' in
height, DO COUNT toward gross floor
area. (Note: Neither appendages like
this nor noise-producing equipment may
be located in the required yards).

All configurations of fireplaces, chimneys, and buttresses
COUNT ONCE towards the gross floor area.
Note: Fireplaces not connected to the house are treated
like accessory structures, they and count towards FAR if
they are greater than 120 sf. They count towards lot
coverage always, regardless of size.

19

visual_elements.description: A line drawing labeled 'Fig 14' illustrating a two-story house with various projections to explain zoning rules. The diagram shows a house with a gabled roof and a covered porch. Several elements are highlighted with pointers and annotations: 1. A chimney on the side of the upper floor is labeled 'Chimneys on the upper floors DO NOT COUNT'. 2. Two large, ground-based chimneys attached to the house are covered by a single annotation: 'All configurations of fireplaces, chimneys, and buttresses COUNT ONCE towards the gross floor area. Note: Fireplaces not connected to the house are treated like accessory structures, they and count towards FAR if they are greater than 120 sf. They count towards lot coverage always, regardless of size.'. 3. A detached shed in the yard is annotated: 'Miscellaneous appendages e.g., tool sheds, equipment enclosures, play houses, etc., that are greater than 5' in height, DO COUNT toward gross floor area. (Note: Neither appendages like this nor noise-producing equipment may be located in the required yards).'. A vertical line with arrows next to the shed indicates its 'Height'.
visual_elements.location: Center of the page, below the main heading and bullet points.

visual_elements.description: A gray-shaded rectangular box containing a note about a Palo Alto ordinance regarding wood-burning fireplaces.
visual_elements.location: Upper right quadrant, partially overlapping the main diagram.

technical_specifications.parameter: Fireplace count in gross floor area
Projection height threshold for gross floor area

structural_elements.main_heading: Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, planters, and other projections

additional_notes: The page number '19' is located in the bottom right corner.
The main rules are presented as two bullet points in a gray-shaded box at the top of the page.
A separate gray-shaded text box in the upper right provides a 'Note' with a cross-reference to a city ordinance.

cross_references.location_on_page: Note box in the upper right quadrant
cross_references.description: Reference for details on a 2000 Palo Alto ordinance prohibiting the construction of new wood-burning fireplaces.

cross_references.location_on_page: Caption below the main bullet points
cross_references.description: Label for the main diagram on the page illustrating rules for fireplaces, chimneys, and sheds.
